**Lela Rochon** (born **Lela Rochon Staples** ; April 17, 1964) is an
[American](/wiki/United_States "United States") actress, best known for her
breakthrough role as Robin Stokes in the 1995 romantic drama film _[Waiting to
Exhale](/wiki/Waiting_to_Exhale "Waiting to Exhale")_.[1] She later had
starring roles in films _[The Chamber](/wiki/The_Chamber_\(film\) "The Chamber
\(film\)")_ (1996), _[Gang Related](/wiki/Gang_Related "Gang Related")_
(1997), _[Knock Off](/wiki/Knock_Off_\(film\) "Knock Off \(film\)")_ (1998),
and _[Why Do Fools Fall in Love](/wiki/Why_Do_Fools_Fall_in_Love_\(film\) "Why
Do Fools Fall in Love \(film\)")_ (1998).

## Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lela_Rochon&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early life")]

Rochon was born in Los Angeles, California, the daughter of Zelma, a nurse
practitioner, and Samuel Staples, a business owner and graphic artist, who are
both of [Haitian](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti") descent.[2][3] She graduated [Cerritos
High School](/wiki/Cerritos_High_School "Cerritos High School") in [Cerritos,
California](/wiki/Cerritos,_California "Cerritos, California"). She attended
[California State University, Dominguez
Hills](/wiki/California_State_University,_Dominguez_Hills "California State
University, Dominguez Hills") where she earned a BA in Broadcast Journalism,
with minors in Sociology and Theatre.[4]

##
Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lela_Rochon&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Career")]

### Early
works[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lela_Rochon&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early works")]

From 1986 to 1988, while attending college, Rochon was one of the "Spudettes"
featured in over 30 national spots for the [Spuds
Mckenzie](/wiki/Spuds_Mckenzie "Spuds Mckenzie") Budweiser/Bud Light TV
commercials. She also appeared in the 1985 made-for-television film _[A
Bunny's Tale](/wiki/A_Bunny%27s_Tale "A Bunny's Tale")_ starring [Kirstie
Alley](/wiki/Kirstie_Alley "Kirstie Alley") and [Delta
Burke](/wiki/Delta_Burke "Delta Burke"), based on [Gloria
Steinem](/wiki/Gloria_Steinem "Gloria Steinem")'s experiences as a [Playboy
Bunny](/wiki/Playboy_Bunny "Playboy Bunny"). She appeared as the love interest
of [Gerald Levert](/wiki/Gerald_Levert "Gerald Levert") in the video for "My
Forever Love" by [Levert](/wiki/LeVert "LeVert"),[5] and in [Luther
Vandross](/wiki/Luther_Vandross "Luther Vandross")'s "It's Over Now" video.
She also appeared in the music video for [Lionel Richie](/wiki/Lionel_Richie
"Lionel Richie")'s single "[All Night Long (All
Night)](/wiki/All_Night_Long_\(All_Night\) "All Night Long \(All Night\)")",
in [Al B. Sure](/wiki/Al_B._Sure "Al B. Sure")'s video for the song
"Natalie".,[6] and in [Tupac Shakur](/wiki/Tupac_Shakur "Tupac Shakur")'s
video "[I Get Around](/wiki/I_Get_Around "I Get Around") as one of the female
dancers. She had many guest starring roles in a number of sitcoms, include
_[The Cosby Show](/wiki/The_Cosby_Show "The Cosby Show")_ ,
_[Amen](/wiki/Amen_\(TV_series\) "Amen \(TV series\)")_ ,
_[227](/wiki/227_\(TV_series\) "227 \(TV series\)")_ , _[The Fresh Prince of
Bel-Air](/wiki/The_Fresh_Prince_of_Bel-Air "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air")_ ,
and _[Hangin' with Mr. Cooper](/wiki/Hangin%27_with_Mr._Cooper "Hangin' with
Mr. Cooper")_.

Rochon made her film debut in 1985, when she starred opposite [Fred
Williamson](/wiki/Fred_Williamson "Fred Williamson") in _Fox Trap_. In 1987,
she played the role of Debby in the film _The Wild Pair_ , starring [Beau
Bridges](/wiki/Beau_Bridges "Beau Bridges") and [Bubba
Smith](/wiki/Bubba_Smith "Bubba Smith"). In 1989, Rochon acted opposite [Eddie
Murphy](/wiki/Eddie_Murphy "Eddie Murphy") in 1989's _[Harlem
Nights](/wiki/Harlem_Nights "Harlem Nights")_ , as the memorable "Sunshine"
character. She again worked with Murphy in the successful 1992 romantic
comedy, _[Boomerang](/wiki/Boomerang_\(1992_film\) "Boomerang \(1992
film\)")_. In 1995, she was regular cast member during the first season of
[The WB](/wiki/The_WB "The WB") sitcom, _[The Wayans
Bros.](/wiki/The_Wayans_Bros. "The Wayans Bros.")_[7]

###
Breakthrough[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lela_Rochon&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Breakthrough")]

Rochon' biggest break came in 1995, when she landed one of the lead roles
opposite [Whitney Houston](/wiki/Whitney_Houston "Whitney Houston"), [Angela
Bassett](/wiki/Angela_Bassett "Angela Bassett") and [Loretta
Devine](/wiki/Loretta_Devine "Loretta Devine") in the adaptation of the [Terry
McMillan](/wiki/Terry_McMillan "Terry McMillan") novel and highly successful
drama film _[Waiting to Exhale](/wiki/Waiting_to_Exhale "Waiting to Exhale")_.
She played the character Robin Stokes, for which she was nominated for an [MTV
Movie Award for Best Breakthrough
Performance](/wiki/MTV_Movie_Award_for_Best_Breakthrough_Performance "MTV
Movie Award for Best Breakthrough Performance") and [NAACP Image Award for
Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Motion
Picture](/wiki/NAACP_Image_Award_for_Outstanding_Supporting_Actress_in_a_Motion_Picture
"NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Motion Picture").
Rochon was chosen by _[People](/wiki/People_\(magazine\) "People
\(magazine\)")_ magazine as one of the "50 most beautiful people in the world"
in 1996.[8]

In 1996, Rochon starred opposite [Timothy Hutton](/wiki/Timothy_Hutton
"Timothy Hutton") in the [Showtime](/wiki/Showtime_\(TV_network\) "Showtime
\(TV network\)") cable network film _Mr. and Mrs. Loving_ , receiving a [Cable
Ace Award](/wiki/Cable_ACE_Awards "Cable ACE Awards") nomination for Best
Actress. Later that year, she played the female lead in the crime thriller
film _[The Chamber](/wiki/The_Chamber_\(film\) "The Chamber \(film\)")_. The
following year, she starred alongside [Jim Belushi](/wiki/Jim_Belushi "Jim
Belushi") and [Tupac Shakur](/wiki/Tupac_Shakur "Tupac Shakur") in the crime
thriller _[Gang Related](/wiki/Gang_Related "Gang Related")_. In 1998, Rochon
had the leading role alongside [Halle Berry](/wiki/Halle_Berry "Halle Berry")
and [Vivica A. Fox](/wiki/Vivica_A._Fox "Vivica A. Fox") in the romantic drama
_[Why Do Fools Fall in Love](/wiki/Why_Do_Fools_Fall_in_Love_\(film\) "Why Do
Fools Fall in Love \(film\)")_ , and well starred in _[Knock
Off](/wiki/Knock_Off_\(film\) "Knock Off \(film\)")_ with [Jean-Claude Van
Damme](/wiki/Jean-Claude_Van_Damme "Jean-Claude Van Damme"), and _[The Big
Hit](/wiki/The_Big_Hit "The Big Hit")_ , as love interest to [Mark
Wahlberg](/wiki/Mark_Wahlberg "Mark Wahlberg")'s leading character. In 1999,
she appeared in _[Any Given Sunday](/wiki/Any_Given_Sunday "Any Given
Sunday")_ directed by [Oliver Stone](/wiki/Oliver_Stone "Oliver Stone"). In
2001, Rochon made her return to television with one of leading roles alongside
[Bonnie Bedelia](/wiki/Bonnie_Bedelia "Bonnie Bedelia"), [Nancy
McKeon](/wiki/Nancy_McKeon "Nancy McKeon"), [Tracey
Needham](/wiki/Tracey_Needham "Tracey Needham"), and [Lisa
Vidal](/wiki/Lisa_Vidal "Lisa Vidal") in the
[Lifetime](/wiki/Lifetime_\(TV_network\) "Lifetime \(TV network\)") crime
drama series, _[The Division](/wiki/The_Division "The Division")_. She left
the series after single season.[9]

###
2000s-present[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lela_Rochon&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: 2000s-present")]

In 2004, Rochon co-starred opposite [Katie Holmes](/wiki/Katie_Holmes "Katie
Holmes") in the romantic comedy film _[First
Daughter](/wiki/First_Daughter_\(2004_film\) "First Daughter \(2004
film\)")_.[9] In 2009, she had cameo in crime drama _[Brooklyn's
Finest](/wiki/Brooklyn%27s_Finest "Brooklyn's Finest")_ directed by her
husband, [Antoine Fuqua](/wiki/Antoine_Fuqua "Antoine Fuqua").[9] In 2013, she
played one of leading roles in [Regina King](/wiki/Regina_King "Regina
King")'s directorial debut _Let The Church Say Amen_ , the film adaptation of
[ReShonda Tate Billingsley](/wiki/ReShonda_Tate_Billingsley "ReShonda Tate
Billingsley")'s 2005 novel for [BET](/wiki/BET "BET").[10] She later had roles
in films _[Supremacy](/wiki/Supremacy_\(film\) "Supremacy \(film\)")_ (2014)
with [Danny Glover](/wiki/Danny_Glover "Danny Glover") and [Derek
Luke](/wiki/Derek_Luke_\(actor\) "Derek Luke \(actor\)"), and
_[Reversion](/w/index.php?title=Reversion_\(2015_film\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Reversion \(2015 film\) \(page does not exist\)")_ (2015), playing [Aja Naomi
King](/wiki/Aja_Naomi_King "Aja Naomi King")'s character's mother.[11][12][13]

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lela_Rochon&action=edit&section=6&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

Rochon was married to actor [Shabba-Doo](/wiki/Shabba-Doo "Shabba-Doo") from
1982 to 1987. In 1999, she married film director [Antoine
Fuqua](/wiki/Antoine_Fuqua "Antoine Fuqua"). Together, they have two children,
Asia and Brando.
